tv.source-info-name: Pluto TV Space guide by TV

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Cosmic Rainbow
programme.desc: In the world of astronomy, how do we overcome the limits imposed by our own eyesight? The universe comes alive by viewing the cosmos in infrared light to gamma radiation.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Stargazer's Paradise
programme.desc: The Atacama desert is a perfect place for watching the night sky. With still winds and only a handful of cloudy nights each year, it allows scientists to get the absolute most out of their tools.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: The Giant Planets: Lords of Gravity
programme.desc: Gravity is one of the most basic and powerful forces shaping our universe. Discover its nature within our own solar system, from the smallest moons to the largest planets.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Outer Limits: Edge of the Solar System
programme.desc: For centuries, it was was thought that Saturn was the most distant planet in our Solar System. With the evolution of the telescope, we discovered the rest of our planets, both elusive and mysterious.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Hidden Havens: Icy Moons
programme.desc: There are hundreds of moons in our solar system. Could one of them be a hidden haven that harbors alien life forms?

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Icy Gems: Frozen Moons
programme.desc: In the far depths of space, out of reach of the Sun's warmth, water can only exist in a super solid state. Some small moons, in fact, are made entirely of ice. What stories do these Icy Gems have to tell about our solar system?

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Shooting Gallery: Asteroids and Comets
programme.desc: Scientist long thought that our solar system consisted of the sun, the planets, and their moons. We soon found that we are far from alone, often coming into contact with asteroids, comets, and other debris.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Galactic Visions: Alien Worlds
programme.desc: The diversity, complexity, and downright beauty of our own solar system is astounding. Could such beauty exist in other parts of the universe as well? Thanks to modern science, we now have the capability to see for ourselves.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Living In Space
programme.desc: How do astronauts cope with living in space? The unique environment, the lack of taste in their food and the smell of canned air all contribute to the stresses of living and working in space.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Atmosphere
programme.desc: How do astronauts cope with living in space?

programme.title: The New Frontier: Flight Status
programme.desc: The latest updates on the new space hardware about to launch us into the next generation of space flight some rockets and capsules are on time others not so fortunate.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Invasion on Mars
programme.desc: The EXO Mars and Curiosity continue their scientific discoveries as we prepare new missions both robotic and manned to the Red planet Mars.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Juno, Cassini and Beyond
programme.desc: The Cassini space craft has completed its mission over Saturn, Juno has reached its target and has commenced its scientific observations of the giant planet Jupiter.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Slingshot
programme.desc: Sending probes throughout the solar system is a mathematicians dream and an engineers nightmare, sling shotting probes around other planets to arrive at their destination.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Living Planet
programme.desc: With continuous observation of arth from orbit scientists have built a data set over time that reveals much about how the Earth breaths and life sustains itself on this living Planet.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Cosmic Collisions
programme.desc: Cosmic and x rays, these mysterious and highly powerful particles from deep space are being investigated to finally discover where they come from.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Gravity
programme.desc: LISA pathfinder, has led the way for a space based gravity wave detector, what are gravity waves and why are they so hard to detect?

programme.title: The New Frontier: Interface
programme.desc: The Ionisphere, where the Earth interfaces with space, is little understood, it effects radio communications, GPS signals and satellites alike.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Night Fire
programme.desc: The Northern Lights are more than just beautiful; they tell us about the make up of our planet, our sun, and may even be a signpost for the possibility of life on other planets.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Virtual Universe
programme.desc: Our understanding of the cosmos is limited by the amount of time we have to see it. Fortunately, computer simulations can help us see how galaxies interact over millions of years, and even how dark matter structures the universe.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Seasons of Saturn
programme.desc: Saturn is the second largest planet and has an astonishing 60 moons in its orbit. Thanks to the Cassini mission, it's also one of the most studied and most photographed planets in our neighborhood.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Vesta Unveiled
programme.desc: With the Dawn missions exploration of the asteroid Vesta and the dwarf planet Ceres, asteroids are a hot topic. See what these incredible missions have uncovered.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Water Worlds
programme.desc: The key ingredient to life in the universe is water. Until recently we thought Earth was the only place in the solar system to have any water at all. Now that probes are peering around nearby worlds we are finding that is just not the case.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Gravity
programme.desc: Gravity has long been a force that has intrigued scientists. Now, for the first time scientists are probing to detect gravity waves in space as well as mapping the gravity patterns of the moon.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Science and the Shuttle
programme.desc: For more than 25 years the shuttle was our ticket to space, and our laboratory in orbit. Uncover the legacy of this amazing machine, and see what lies ahead.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Landing on Mars
programme.desc: Mars sparks our curiosity like no other planet because it is so reachable. Despite having landed there, most of the information we gather is still done by instruments in the planet's orbit.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: Milky Way
programme.desc: This episode traces our view of the Milky Way, from the mythology of ancient sky watchers to the efforts of scientists to map it from the inside out.

programme.title: Cosmic Vistas: The Big Bang
programme.desc: Throughout history, our nightly view of the universe has fueled our collective imagination. When it comes to the Big Bang, not even the most creative work of imagination can rival what science has revealed about the birth of the universe.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Living In Space
programme.desc: How do astronauts cope with living in space? The unique environment, the lack of taste in their food and the smell of canned air all contribute to the stresses of living and working in space.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Atmosphere
programme.desc: How do astronauts cope with living in space?

programme.desc: The latest updates on the new space hardware about to launch us into the next generation of space flight some rockets and capsules are on time others not so fortunate.

programme.desc: The EXO Mars and Curiosity continue their scientific discoveries as we prepare new missions both robotic and manned to the Red planet Mars.

programme.desc: The Cassini space craft has completed its mission over Saturn, Juno has reached its target and has commenced its scientific observations of the giant planet Jupiter.

programme.desc: With continuous observation of arth from orbit scientists have built a data set over time that reveals much about how the Earth breaths and life sustains itself on this living Planet.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Cosmic Collisions
programme.desc: Cosmic and x rays, these mysterious and highly powerful particles from deep space are being investigated to finally discover where they come from.

programme.title: The New Frontier: Gravity
programme.desc: LISA pathfinder, has led the way for a space based gravity wave detector, what are gravity waves and why are they so hard to detect?

programme.title: The New Frontier: Interface
programme.desc: The Ionisphere, where the Earth interfaces with space, is little understood, it effects radio communications, GPS signals and satellites alike.

programme.title: Meteorite Men: Chile 1: Imilac & Vaca Muerta
programme.desc: In the first-ever overseas Meteorite Men episode Steve and Geoff revisit the very site where their hunting partnership began way back in 1997: the Imilac pallasite strewnfield high in Chile's Atacama Desert.
